bboxes.raw_text:
ST. LOUIS, Mo. St. Louis
metropolitan area branches of the
National Association for the Adj
vancement of Colored People
have launched selective-buying
campaign against Lever Bro
theirs. The drive is aimed at
getting more Negroes on the COM
panys payroll.


Scores of NAACP volunteer
workers have been taking up sta
tions outside of major stores and
supermarkets in the area passing
out handbills urging shoppers not
to purchase Lever Brothers pro-
ducts.


These include the following
soaps and detergents: Dove, Lux,
Lifeboy, Swan, All, Breeze, Rim
so, Surf and Wisk; toothpaste
Pops odent and Stripe: margar-
inc: Imperial and Good Luck;
Spry shortening; Birds-Eye fro
zen foods; and Upton teas and
soups.


Efforts are under way TO ex-
pand the no-buy drive nationally.
According to Ernest Galloway,
first vice-president of the st.
Louis NAACP branch and direc-
tor Of the campaign; branches in
other cities where Lever Bro
theirs operate plants are being
urged to launch no-buy drives.
The cities are Baltimore, Md,
Chicago, Ill, Los Angeles, Calf,
Hammond, Ind, and Edgewater,
N. ].


The campaign was instituted
after repeated efforts to contact
company officials to discuss Le-
yer Brothers policy of Negro
lob tokenism," NAACP leaders
said. An NAACP Investigations
said to have revealed that the
company employs only seven Ne
cores in a force of 375 in St.
Louis. Nationally, the firm is
reported to have approximately
5000 employees of which less
than five per cent are Negroes.

Mrs. Rosa Williams Edwards
has been invited to attend the
Western Regional Conference for
women's organizations of the
President Committee for Traf-
fic Safety.


The meeting will be held at the
Sheraton-Palace Hotel in San
Francisco, May As.


The women's groups are en-
phasizing the need for halting the
rising traffic death rates mall OF
the fifty states.


Delegates from various or
ganizations including CIVIC
church and community groups
will attend.

Mrs. Edwards Invited
To Attend Traffic Meet

May 2-Cocktail sip at Mr.. and
Mrs. Arthur Blackshear S home,
1917 S. Is Drive.


May 3-City oratorical contest
Southminster Pre- byte r1a n
Church, 1923 E. Broadway Rd.,
8 pm.


PISA presidents Emmett H. Hair
rison and Bessie /. Smith; sec
retaries John Adams and Ger
trude Bradley made the final in
spection tour for the planning OF
the PISA convention. The conven-
ton was confirmed and it will be
held in the city June 24-2o.


Mai. Gen. Matthew W. Lips
combe, 1t. Col. A. Thompson, Dt.
Luthermae Adams, state secre-
tary attended, also.


Dispensation is still OPEN
Temple membership drive ends
June 30.

NASHVILLE Violent demon
strations resulted in the injury
of 10 Negroes and seven po-
licemen.


Most of the demonstrators
we're teenagers who formed lines
in front of two segregated bust
nesses. They lay in the streets
and police used nightsticks to
force them back.


One Negro girl was takento the
hospital unconscious. Police
threatened to use fire hoses.

STATESVILLE, N. G. A Neg
70 insurance agent seeking cleo
tion to the Iredell County Board
of Commissioners was found dead
in a wooded area near States
Vile.


Benjamin Sanford Carlton, At,
of Statesville, had shotgun
wound in his upper chest.


Sheriff &c. Rumple said Carl
tons .4lO gauge shotgun was
found in his car, 81 feet from
the body. Rumple said there was
blood in and near the car but
there we're no signs of struggle.

Negro Cundidute Killed
By Shotgun Fire

The 44th annual communica-
ton of the Most Worshipful
Prince Hall Grand Lodge, Free
and Accepted Mas ons of Arizona
Jurisdiction and the 43rd annual
communication of the Sovereign
Grand Chapter, Order of the
Eastern Star, will convene in
Phoenix, May 9Th.


A welcoming program will be
held at Tanner Chapel AME
Church, located at 9th St. and
Jefferson. Rev. L. K. Williams
will address the group.


Business sessions will open
Monday, May 4, 9 am at the
Masonic Temple, 4th and JEFF
ferson.


S. C. Boyer is the grand mas
ter.


The Grand Chapter will open
meetings We'd, May E at 9 am.


Mrs. Laura Franklin is the
grand worthy matron.
